comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: Several other description (A), B), and C)) have been discussed during some of our meeting. Which description of "Demand" fits best in SC4EU? A) - Outgoing/ incoming Shipments (bound by capacity, mostly not directly forecasted, mostly historic values) B -  Outgoing (downstream)/ Incoming (upstream) Orders (already inflated and don’t reflect actual sales because of order cancellations) or C) - Confirmed orders.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
True demand refers to the actual market need for a product, independent of any distortions caused by safety stocks, ordering behavior, or supply constraints.     In constrained situations, customer orders are not a good indicator of true demand.” Instead, demand visibility efforts aim to reconstruct or approximate true demand to support better planning and long-term capacity decisions . Understanding true demand is essential for: 
    Avoiding over- or under-capacity planning
    Smoothing production schedules
    Ensuring strategic alignment of resources

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: @Claude. Your description is better. My description is obsolete. Latest view is that True Demand = End Market Demand

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: This represents the number of days, weeks, or months of future demand that the desired inventory level is expected to cover.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: The Pork Cycle is is een as a metaphor for boom-and-bust investment cycles caused by delayed supply responses to demand fluctuations. The result is the potential for large-scale boom and bust cycles reminiscent of the ‘pork cycle’ in agricultural economics.The delayed response of supply to demand, combined with uncertain forecasts and large capital requirements, gives rise to classic cyclicality.  It describes how overinvestment during shortages leads to future overcapacity, followed by price crashes and underinvestment, perpetuating the cycle.

comments.author: Felix Engel
comments.content: @Robert Claude provided another definition. What do you think about it?

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: Claude's text is quite ok. It is not clear what 'classic cyclicality' means here. And the investments do not have to be large. And it only happens in industries that grow, such as semiconductors, or where the life time of capacity is limited, such as pork. And it can also happen if demand is stable (but that will only become clear after our article on the pork cycle has been published).

comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: I guess that "Desired Utilization Rate (DUR)" is rather a alternative label and "See Also". I have revised accordingly

comments.author: felix
comments.content: Robert proposed a different definition: "Estimating a smooth trend, usually be taking weighted averages of observations. The term smoothed is used because such averages tend to reduce randomness by allowing positive and negative random effects to partially offset each other."

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: The bullwhip effect refers to demand distortions that amplify as information moves upstream in the supply chain, often due to forecast updates, order batching, and demand signal processing.

comments.author: felix engel
comments.content:
NXP sees demand as incoming requested orders (inflated and biased by “panic buying”)
Expressed in absolute quantities (what we expect to ship). Slideset: WP5_26_06_2024

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Short-term demand refers to forecasted or actual demand over a short planning horizon—typically days or weeks. It is used for near-term scheduling and order fulfilment decisions.

comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: I have added a definition that describes how I would define the term. Any feedback on it?

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
Semantic technology refers to a set of technologies that enable machines to understand, interpret, and reason about data through its meaning rather than just its structure.
In the semiconductor supply chain context, semantic technologies help integrate diverse data sources, improve interoperability, and support decision-making by linking data through shared vocabularies and ontologies.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Curation refers to the activity of cleaning, validating, or processing data within the supply chain. It ensures that data (such as orders, inventory, customers, etc.) are complete, accurate, and usable.

comments.author: felix engel
comments.content: It is somewhat lengthy, but as such hopefully explanatory

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
These are standardized frameworks developed by the W3C to support the development of the Semantic Web. They include RDF (Resource Description Framework), OWL (Web Ontology Language), and SPARQL (query language).
In the documents, these standards underpin efforts to create digitally interoperable supply chains using structured knowledge models. These concepts support advanced systems like decision support, supply chain analytics, and digital twins by enriching raw data with context and relationships.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content:
The description still does not say what a Semantic Web is. It is helping and it has a goal. It refers to a vision of linked data. But what is said vision? What are rules for handling data? 

And who is W3C?

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
The Semantic Web is an extension of the current web that enables data to be shared and reused across applications, enterprises, and communities by attaching meaning (semantics) to the data.
It plays a role in the digital reference ontologies mentioned in the documents, supporting intelligent data access and reasoning in distributed systems.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: Claude's description is much better. @Claude: What is the 'current web'? The www? Mentioned in which 'documents'? @Felix: Shall we add 'distributed systems' and 'intelligent data access' also to this vocabulary?

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: "A semiconductor fabrication plant (commonly called a fab; sometimes foundry) is a factory for semiconductor device fabrication." (wiki). This is correct in my view. The DR description is nonsense.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: A fab (short for fabrication plant) is a manufacturing facility where semiconductor wafers are processed to produce integrated circuits.

comments.author: Robert
comments.content: A fab (short for fabrication plant) is a manufacturing facility where semiconductor wafers (discs containing integrated circuits) are produced.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
Front end" refers to the initial phases of the production process, primarily wafer fabrication and wafer probe.
These stages involve creating the integrated circuits on silicon wafers using processes like photolithography, doping, etching, and deposition. Wafer fabrication and probe are generally referred to as front-end operations.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: efers to the assembly and test stages of semiconductor manufacturing, typically occurring after wafer fabrication (front end).

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: A chip is a small piece of semiconducting material on which an integrated circuit is embedded. Also known as a die.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: A die bank is a stock of tested but unpackaged semiconductor dies stored after wafer dicing, enabling flexibility in packaging and fulfillment.

comments.author: Adrien Wartelle
comments.content: Proposition: Maximum Amount of products that can be produced in a given amount of time. In semiconductor manufacturing, these amounts can quantified as a number of wafers (or lots of wafers) produced per week for Front End and the number of integrated chips for Back End.

comments.author: Adrien Wartelle
comments.content: * More specifically Bottleneck refers to the production resources that are limiting this maximal amount

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Planning refers to the set of activities aimed at aligning supply capabilities with demand requirements over different time horizons, under constraints of capacity, material availability, and manufacturing lead times. Planning activities attempt to reconcile the demand picture with the supply picture to ensure delivery of committed products and optimize fab performance.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Sales demand refers to the quantity of a product that the sales organization expects to sell or has committed to sell over a given period. It may include firm customer orders, sales forecasts, or strategic targets.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
Supply-demand match refers to the alignment between what is available (supply) and what is needed (demand), considering timing, quantities, and product configurations.
In constrained environments, this matching process often requires optimization to balance competing priorities, such as customer service level and inventory efficiency.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
The supply picture is a representation of the total available and projected supply both inventory and production over a planning horizon.
It provides visibility for planners to assess whether and how current and planned supply can meet demand.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
A target refers to a defined objective or performance goal in the supply chain such as desired inventory levels, service levels, or utilization rates.
Targets guide decision-making in planning, allocation, and scheduling.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
In the supply chain context, time is a key dimension across all planning activities, representing lead times, cycle times, delivery windows, and time fences for freezing plans.
Time is often segmented into discrete buckets (e.g., daily, weekly, monthly) for operational and strategic planning.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Allocation refers to the process of assigning available supply to customer orders, especially when demand exceeds supply. It is often governed by predefined rules or priorities to manage shortages effectively.

comments.author: Claude Yugma

comments.content: Demand trace is the tracking of demand from final customer requests through the supply chain, enabling visibility of demand origins and fulfillment status.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Demand represents the quantity of products requested by customers. It can be firm (confirmed orders) or forecast-based. It is a critical driver in supply chain operations.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content:
Demand fulfilment refers to the set of processes by which a company responds to customer demand by delivering products or services. In the semiconductor supply chain, it includes order promising, product allocation, scheduling, and ensuring timely delivery.
It represents the interface between the supply chain and external customers, ensuring that demand is met in accordance with business rules and available resources. It represents the interface between the supply chain and its external customers.”
It also connects closely with Available to Promise (ATP) mechanisms that decide what can be committed to customers based on current and projected inventory and capacity.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: A demand snapshot is a fixed capture of demand data at a given point in time. It allows comparison over time or alignment between supply and demand planning cycles.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: A supply chain is the network of organizations, resources, activities, and technologies involved in the production and delivery of a product from raw materials to the final customer. Supply chain management issues have become increasingly important to the semiconductor industry due to the global distribution of facilities and increasing numbers of firms specialising in particular stages.

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: A partner refers to any external organization that collaborates within the supply network, such as foundries, OSATs (outsourced semiconductor assembly and test providers), EDA tool vendors, equipment suppliers, or logistics providers.

comments.author: felix
comments.content: I assume that "Reactive stocking" is an alternative Label and not a reference. I will change accordingly

comments.author: Claude Yugma
comments.content: Wafer fabrication is the core front-end process in semiconductor manufacturing where integrated circuits (ICs) are created on the surface of silicon wafers. It is also seen as the process by which ICs are produced is one of the most complex technological achievements of the twentieth century… A CMOS manufacturing process of even modest complexity can involve hundreds of unit operations, up to forty layers of material, several hundred individual pieces of production equipment (referred to as tools), and average cycle times of the order of 10–15 weeks
